sen.j: 綾戸國中神社（あやとくなかじんじゃ）は、京都府京都市南区 (京都市)にある神社である。
sen.e: Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Minami Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Minami Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Minami Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 祇園祭は当社と八坂神社との祭礼である。
sen.e: The Gion Festival is held by Yasaka-jinja Shrine and Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.
The Gion Festival is held by Yasaka-jinja Shrine and Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.
The Gion Festival is held by Yasaka-jinja Shrine and Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 元は綾戸神社・國中神社の二社であったが、後に國中神社が綾戸神社の境内に遷された。
sen.e: It was originally the two separate shrines Ayato-jinja Shrine and Kunaka-jinja Shrine but Kunaka-jinja Shrine was later relocated into the precinct of Ayato-jinja Shrine.
It was originally the two separate shrines Ayato-jinja Shrine and Kunaka-jinja Shrine but Kunaka-jinja Shrine was later relocated into the precinct of Ayato-jinja Shrine.
It was originally the two separate shrines Ayato-jinja Shrine and Kunaka-jinja Shrine but Kunaka-jinja Shrine was later relocated into the precinct of Ayato-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: それ以降、2つの社殿が並んでいたが、昭和9年の台風により倒壊したため、昭和11年に1つの社殿として再建した。
sen.e: Following this, the shrine consisted of two buildings but these were destroyed by a typhoon in 1934 and rebuilt as a single building in 1936.
Following this, the shrine consisted of two buildings but these were destroyed by a typhoon in 1934 and rebuilt as a single building in 1936.
Following this, the shrine consisted of two buildings but these were destroyed by a typhoon in 1934 and rebuilt as a single building in 1936.

sen.j: 昭和39年、境内地が東海道新幹線建設予定地にかかったため、現在地に遷座した。
sen.e: The shrine was relocated to its current location after the precinct was scheduled as a site for the construction of the Tokaido Shinkansen in 1964.
The shrine was relocated to its current location after the precinct was scheduled as a site for the construction of the Tokaido Shinkansen in 1964.
The shrine was relocated to its current location after the precinct was scheduled as a site for the construction of the Tokaido Shinkansen in 1964.
Ayato-jinja Shrine
Ayato-jinja Shrine
Ayato-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 大綾津日神、大直日神、神直日神を祀る。
sen.e: Enshrines Oayatsuhi no kami, Onaohi no kami and Kamunaoni no kami.
Enshrines Oayatsuhi no kami, Onaohi no kami and Kamunaoni no kami.
Enshrines Oayatsuhi no kami, Onaohi no kami and Kamunaoni no kami.

sen.j: 継体天皇15年の創建と伝えられ、かつては大井川（桂川 (淀川水系)）の祓神として大井社と称していたが、天暦9年（955年）に綾戸社に改称した。
sen.e: Said to have been constructed in the 15th year of the reign of Emperor Keitai and was previous named Oi-sha Shrine after the harai-gami of Oi-gawa River (Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system)) but was renamed Ayato-sha Shrine in the year 995.

Said to have been constructed in the 15th year of the reign of Emperor Keitai and was previous named Oi-sha Shrine after the harai-gami of Oi-gawa River (Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system)) but was renamed Ayato-sha Shrine in the year 995.

Said to have been constructed in 521 and was previous named Oi-sha Shrine after the harai-gami of Oi-gawa River (Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system)) but was renamed Ayato-sha Shrine in the year 995.

sen.j: それ以降も、近代までは「大井社」とも呼ばれていた。
sen.e: However, it was still referred to by the name "Oi-sha Shrine" until modern times.
However, it was still referred to by the name "Oi-sha Shrine" until modern times.
However, it was still referred to by the name 'Oi-sha Shrine' until modern times.

sen.j: 古くより上久世の産土神として信仰される。
sen.e: Since ancient times, the shrine has been worshipped for the guardian deity of Kamikuze.
Since ancient times, the shrine has been worshipped for the guardian deity of Kamikuze.
Since ancient times, the shrine has been worshipped for the guardian deity of Kamikuze.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳記載の「山城國乙訓郡 茨田神社」あるいは「大井神社」の論社の一つである。
sen.e: It is thought to be either "Mata-jinja Shrine in Otokuni-County, Yamashiro Province" or "Oi-jinja Shrine" which are listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

It is thought to be either "Mata-jinja Shrine in Otokuni-County, Yamashiro Province" or "Oi-jinja Shrine" which are listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

It is thought to be either 'Mata-jinja Shrine in Otokuni-County, Yamashiro Province' or 'Oi-jinja Shrine' which are listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
Kunaka-jinja Shrine
Kunaka-jinja Shrine
Kunaka-jinja Shrine
Enshrines Susanoo.
Enshrines Susanoo.
Enshrines Susanoo.

sen.j: 社伝によれば、附近一帯が湖水に覆われていたころ、素盞嗚尊が天降って水を切り流し、その中心に愛馬の頭を彫刻したものを尊の形見として祀ったのに始まるという。
sen.e: According to shrine legend, when the entire surrounding area was covered by a lake, Susanoo no mikoto descended and drained the water, after which the shrine was established when a carving of the head of his favorite horse was enshrined at the center of the site.

According to shrine legend, when the entire surrounding area was covered by a lake, Susanoo no mikoto descended and drained the water, after which the shrine was established when a carving of the head of his favorite horse was enshrined at the center of the site.

According to shrine legend, when the entire surrounding area was covered by a lake, Susanoo no mikoto descended and drained the water, after which the shrine was established when a carving of the head of his favorite horse was enshrined at the center of the site.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳記載の「山城國乙訓郡 國中神社」の論社の一つである。
sen.e: It is thought to be "Kunaka-jinja Shrine in Otokuni-County, Yamashiro Province" which is listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
It is thought to be "Kunaka-jinja Shrine in Otokuni-County, Yamashiro Province" which is listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

Festivals
Festivals
Festivals

sen.j: 祇園祭の久世駒形稚児はこの神社の氏子から選ばれる。
sen.e: The Gion Festival Kuze Komagata chigo are chosen from the parishioners of Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.
The Gion Festival Kuze Komagata chigo are chosen from the parishioners of Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.
The Gion Festival Kuze Komagata chigo are chosen from the parishioners of Ayatokunaka-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 久世駒形稚児は祇園祭の神幸祭・還幸祭で、馬に乗って、素戔嗚尊（すさのおのみこと）が鎮まる中御座神輿（なかござみこし）の先導を務めるが、この際に胸にかける木彫りの馬の首（駒形）は國中社の神体を模したものである。
sen.e: Kuze Komagata chigo are children who ride on horseback as they lead the Nakagoza mikoshi (portable shrine) enshrining Susanoo no mikoto and carry around their necks the object of worship of Kunaka-jinja Shrine, a horse head carved out of wood (komagata), in the "Shinko-sai" and "Kanko-sai" rituals.

Kuze Komagata chigo are children who ride on horseback as they lead the Nakagoza mikoshi (portable shrine) enshrining Susanoo no mikoto and carry around their necks the object of worship of Kunaka-jinja Shrine, a horse head carved out of wood (komagata), in the "Shinko-sai" and "Kanko-sai" rituals.

Kuze Komagata chigo are children who ride on horseback as they lead the Nakagoza mikoshi (portable shrine) enshrining Susanoo no mikoto and carry around their necks the object of worship of Kunaka-jinja Shrine, a horse head carved out of wood (komagata), in the Shinko-sai and Kanko-sai rituals.
